titleStmt.title: A true report of the most execrable murder committed vpon the late French King Henrie the 4. of famous memory with diuers particularities aswell concerning the prisoner, as other matters preceding and ensuing the accident. Written in a letter from good place, and much differing from the vncertaine relations thereof heretofore published.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

Full documentation of the original data capture process is available from the Text Creation Partnership web site. All versions of the texts are now archived and freely available for download. See the TCP Download FAQ for detailed information. The TEI P5 versions are also freely available from the TCP Github repository.

div.p: A TRVE REPORT of the most execrable Murder committed vpon the late French King Henrie the 4. of famous memory, with diuers particularities aswell concerning the Prisoner, as other matters preceding and ensuing the accident. Written in a Letter from good place, and much differing from the vncertaine relations thereof heretofore published.

figure.figDesc: Woodcut portrait of King Henri IV, in ruff and doublet.

div.p: AT LONDON, ✿ Printed for Iohn Budge, and are to be sold at his shop in Brittaine Burse. An. 1610. ({inverted ⁂})

div.head: A COPIE OF A Letter from Paris 17. of May, declaring the māner of the French kings murder, & other particularities therevpon depending.

div.opener: SIR, the misfortune of our France hath hitherto so amazed mee, that I could not possibly write vnto you how it was, but now that the consideration of the euill (without remedie) hath giuen mee time to breath, I will performe the dutie I owe you in letting you know it, and thus it happened.
div.p:
A Mischieuous villaine called Francis Rauaillart, and borne at Angolesme, now prisoner in the Cōsergerie of the Pallace of Paris, confesseth that more than these 8. moneths he hath sought occasiō
to kill the King, because hee suffered two Religions in his Kingdome, but could not find the meanes to doe it vntill the fourteenth of May last, A daye which many Astrologians haue iudged fatall to his Maiesty, wherof he was aduertised both by the Queene, and by Mons r. de Vendosme, with request not to goe abroad that day. But hee (not belieuing Predictions) sayd, that it was an offence to God to giue credit vnto them, and that hauing God for his guarde hee feared no man; yet was hee almost all that morning at his prayers, and then went to walke at the Tuilleries, where being in the great Gallerie, this wretch thought to execute his deseigne, but being put by by Mons r. de Vendosme, talking with the King, hee resolued to attempt him no further at that time, but returned to attend at the Lovre, where he tarryed vntill foure of the clocke in the afternoone, sitting vppon the steppes of the hall, making
shew onely to behold the lackies playing in the Court. At which time the King caused his Coach to bee brought to goe to the Arcenale to see Mons r. de Sullie who was there somewhat in indisposition. The King sat in the hinder end of the Coach accompanyed with the Dukes de Vendosme, Montbasson d' Espernon, and Mons r. le Grand, and so went forward without suffering any of his Guarde to follow him, being very confident, and yet after dinner before he went out of his Cabinet, he fell to his prayers againe within his wardrobe.

Passing through the streete called la Ferronerie, which leadeth into Saint Denis street, a Cart or Waggon crost his Coach and caused it to stoppe. This villaine which followed it (seeing the King behind in the Coach leaning towards the boote thereof, to talke with Mons r. d' Espernon; and being without a cloake to put his arme out at the open
place betwixt the two hindermost pillars of the Coach, and so the left side naked without defence of his arme, which the King in talking leaned vpon on the other side) stabbed at him with a knife of a foote long, but the thrust ranne a long the third ribbe and was not deadly. Whereat the King crying I am hurt, but it is nothing, this cursed wretch redoubled his blowe, which went right to the heart, and would haue giuen him the third, but that Mons r. de Montbasson caught hold of his arme. At this second blowe his Maiestie fell downe vppon his face dead, and was carryed to the Lovre, where the Queen was, reposing her selfe after the great trauaile shee endured the daye before at her coronation.

This great Princesse beholding this sad spectacle, fell twice into a swound, (the generositie of her minde and the greatnesse of her sorrowe, stopping the
fountaine of teares.) Then comming to her selfe againe, with a manly courage pluckt vp her spirits, and commanded the Dukes de Guise, and d' Espernon, (being the principall of those shee sawe about her) to giue order for the safety of the young King and his bretheren, and of the Citty of Paris, which they promised to doe: and going out of the Chamber embraced one another, and sware friendshippe and loue, with protestation neuer to remember old enmitie. The like did Mons r. d' Espernon to Mons r. Montigny, with-whome meeting, he sayd, Sir, you and your brother are the men to whome I haue wished most harme of any in the world, but now I will bee a friend to you both, and doe praye you to bee so to mee, to the end wee may the better serue our King and our country.

The sayd Duke d' Espernon that daye shewed great effects of his fidelity, for
with the Regiment of Guards hee secured the King, Queene, and late kings Children, and also the Citty of Paris, setting Courts of guard in all publicke places, which notwithstand were of no vse.

For the poore people were so confused with sorrowe, that a man could see them doe nothing else but goe wayling vp and downe the streetes, lamenting the losse of their King. Insomuch as they durst not carrye this wretched villaine to prison, for feare the sorrowe of the people should haue turned into furie vppon him, so that hee was faine to be kept Foure and twenty houres at the Hostell de Retts.

The same daye the Marshalles of Fraunce and Officers of the Crowne, tooke their oaths to the King & Queen, and the Parliament assembling at sixe of the clocke in the euening, declared the
Queene Regent during the minoritie of her Sonne, and prayed her to bring the King to the Pallace the next daye, to sit vppon his seate of Iustice, and so he did.

The King was accompanyed with the Prince of Conty, the Duke d' Anguien (the Counte Soissons being absent) and with the Dukes de Guise, de Sullie, and d' Espernon, and with the Marshalles of Fraunce, Lavardin, Brisac, and Boy-dolphin.
Mons r. de Fervaques was sent away in the night by the Queenes commaundement to goe to his gouernment, so also was Mons r. S. Pole, and many other gouernours.

All those which accompanyed the King were on foote; the Constable, Cardinalles, and Ecclesiasticall Peeres were gone before to take their places, and so
was the Duke de Mayne.

Counte Soissons arrived on Monday following the Seauenteenth of this moneth, about twoo of the clocke after noone, accompanied with Fiue hundred Horses, of those which hee brought with him, and such as went forth to meete him, two Marshalles of Fraunce going to him to Saint Clou, where hee dyned.

Hee alighted at the Lovre, and comming to the Queenes presence, gaue testimonie by his teares, that he participated of her greefe: He promised the King all assistance, euen to the last drop of his bloud.
Mons r. Prasline was dispatched away to the armie, to holde some order of discipline vntill the cōming of the Dukes de Neuers and Bullion.
Thus Sir you see what doth and hath passed in this afflicted Court vntill this present, which I send you for certaine truth, and so cease till future occurents giue occasion of further aduertisement.
